description: Base -2 representation of -n reinterpreted as binary.
references: M. Gardner, Knotted Doughnuts and Other Mathematical Entertainments. Freeman, NY, 1986, p. 101.
N. J. A. Sloane and Simon Plouffe, The Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences, Academic Press, 1995 (includes this sequence).
links: Joerg Arndt, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..1000
example: a(4) = 12 because the negabinary representation of -4 is 1100, and in ordinary binary that is 12.a(5) = 15 because the negabinary representation of -5 is 1111, and in binary that is 15.
mathematica: (* This function comes from the Weisstein page *)Negabinary[n_Integer] := Module[{t = (2/3)(4^Floor[Log[4, Abs[n] + 1] + 2] - 1)}, IntegerDigits[BitXor[n + t, t], 2]];Table[FromDigits[Negabinary[n], 2], {n, -1, -50, -1}](* _Alonso del Arte_, Apr 04 2011 *)
crossrefs: Complement of A005351 in natural numbers.
author: _N. J. A. Sloane_.
